div.p: Viennese music autographer, who produced many of the finest of Schenker's Urlinie-Tafeln.

div.head: Tomay: man and company
div.p: Tomay's stamped letterhead reads: Spezialanstalt für Musikalische Arbeiten [Special office for musical works] /‒ Georg Tomay ‒ / Wien, I., Fichtegasse 1a Tel. R. 22-419.
(Fichtegasse crosses the Ringstraße close to the Stadtpark.) Tomay signed his engraving work: Autographie Gg. Tomay Wien I.

Georg Tomay originated the extensive graphs for Schenker’s essay on Beethoven’s "Eroica" Symphony in Das Meisterwerk in der Musik, vol. III (Munich: Drei Masken Verlag, 1930), also the Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln / Five Analyses in Sketchform (New York: David Mannes Music School, 1932) and all the examples of Der freie Satz.

Autography (Autographie) is a transfer-print process that obviates the necessity of incising an image into a metal plate (engraving). By this process, the initial image (in Schenker's case music notation or a voice-leading graph) is inscribed the right way round (whereas engraving is done in reverse) on a specially prepared paper using a specialized ink; the resulting sheet is lightly pressed on to a damp lithographic stone or metal plate, causing the image to transfer.

Schenker's opinion of Tomay's work is expressed upon seeing the finished Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln: he wrote to Felix Salzer: The folios are of the noblest beauty, a new unicum as a publication, quite apart from the content. To express appreciation of the external appearance and the content every reader must become ‒ a poet. (FS 40/1, [10], July 16, 1932).

div.head: Correspondence between Tomay and Schenker
div.p: Twenty-three items of correspondence survive between Georg Tomay and Schenker, all preserved within the correspondence between Schenker and Drei Masken Verlag and numbered OC 54/196‒217, 343 and 350: from Tomay to Schenker: fourteen handwritten letters, receipts for payment, two invoices, and postal receipts; from Schenker to Tomay: eight postal receipts (no items known to survive). These items date between June 23, 1930 and May 4, 1932; all concern "work on the music examples (Figuren) and Urlinien" for Das Meisterwerk in der Musik vol. III, i.e. all the examples and graphs for Schenker's study of the "Eroica" Symphony. There are also many references to Tomay in Schenker's diaries and correspondence.
